author: fossie

description.text:
This is a project to make a lamp from a rhinoceros head.
I've used a 3D scan done by users of the Rhinoceros Sculpture in front of the Orsay Museum in Paris (https://www.myminifactory.com/fr/object/rhinoceros-at-the-museum-d-orsay-paris-6314).
I've extracted the head, and mix it with screw design (screw done thanks to this exellent tutorial for sketchup:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0F0xBh9fi5o ) in meshmixer.
The base is not yet finished, but will receive (or you can help me to make it), a LED lamp inside. I'm about to make some electronic design and will upload it when it'll done...

In summary the process is:

  • using a 3D scan of the sclupture
  • cut the head via Meshmixer
  • design the screw in sketchup
  • merge parts with Meshmixer (check well "make solid" in the junction sites of screw/head is well done)
  • design the other parts of screw and base of the lamp in sketchup. Let 0,5mm space between pieces (otherwise when it'll not be easy to move pieces between each other)
  • use in meshmixer the ability to make support (I like it very much - you'll have both designs in the object - with or without support)
  • print in PLA (take around 20hours for the head, 11 for the base)

I've added a led lamp inside, 12V, very easy.

thanks

description.text:
Outer geometry
  • The outer geometry has one depression for each of its 3 corners
  • The yellow corner ascends
  • The red corner descends
  • The blue corner remains parallel to the base
    Inner geometry
  • The inner geometry has the same 3 depressions, the colors matching as well
  • The inner geometry revolves in its own axis, inside the inner geometry
    • Game description
  • The inner geometry starts as shown in picture #1
  • Balls are introduced randomly into each of depressions
  • The inner geometry will revolve until the closest depressions are aligned with the outer geometry
  • Before the turn of the inner geometry, the student will have to determine how many balls will remain in each of depressions after the turn, considering:
    A- One turn to the left
    B- One turn to the right
    C- Two turns to the left or right ( and so on)
    • The objective of the game is:
  • Learn how to calculate using different variables
  • Develop a flexible memory
  • Develop causality relations (ascend, descend, remain, colors and its combinations)
Hasnt been made yet, its just the Design

author: Smoozi_ldz

description.text:
To see more information, you can watch this video: https://youtu.be/n8OhpEBMrQc

This week I'm bringing you guys the Omnidroid from the Incredibles. I modeled this in Fusion 360 using sketches and various tools to get the shapes here.

It's mostly simple shapes like a big sphere with smaller spheres attaching the legs. The feet are pretty basic shapes that are arranged in a plus shape. The legs are really where the bulk of the design work comes in. You can see what I did in the video but I basically just took a sketched line, and lofted a rectangle shape along the line. Then I created an 's' shape on the side of it and patterned that long the path of the leg.

Then after I printed it (settings below), my wife sanded it, sprayed it with filler primer and sanded it some more. Then she used her airbrush to paint it black. The only thing left after that was to paint the eye red. She did this with a paintbrush and some acrylic paint.

Print Settings:
Printer: Robo3D R1
Filament: Hatchbox PLA
Layer Height: 0.3mm
Infill: 20%
Supports: Yes
Raft: Yes

Prove to yourself that the area of a parallelogram is the base times the height. Here's an overview video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wC8gYuBQaK4 Three puzzle sets are provided. Each set can be arranged to form the same rectangle and rearranged to form different parallelograms with the same area. Teachers: Have students follow the Exploration Guide (pdf file). It asks some good questions to get them thinking mathematically. Here are the Common Core standards associated with this manipulative: 3.MD.5, 3MD.8 and 4.MD.3 I've included the source files (SketchUp) in a zip archive.

Print out the base container and the three puzzle sets and follow the exploration guide. Here are the colors I used in the video: BLACK: Base container (with white text, see below)
ORANGE: Puzzle Set A
YELLOW: Puzzle Set B
GREEN: Puzzle Set C I don't have dual extrusion on my printer, so to get the white-on-black for the container, I started with black then paused the printing at 4mm and switched to white filament. Looking forward to learning how to make dual extrusion files soon. Note: If puzzle set C doesn't fit right, try the alternate version.

A math manipulative meant to help teach angles to students.
This game includes one bowling pin a hammer, base and various angle pieces of different sizes.
The hammer twists around nearly 360.
One player places the bowling pin around the base, the other uses the available pieces and estimates the pieces required to create the angle that aligns the hammer and the pin. Place the angle pieces between the blue and red sections of the base, swing the hammer to see if you were right!
To adjust the difficulty level, change the number of angle pieces available. Angles can be printed on the underside of the angle pieces.
I created this in 123Design Online after wasting a few cocktail napkins :-)

description.text:
Simplified and more compact mod of the FlyPi (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:905172). Here the camera with auto focus drive is integrated into the base of the system for robustness and easy use.

Note that in this configuration the Peltier Thermistor control loop is not available. All other FlyPi modules should still work with this, though.

Here shown to magnify a bunch of mosquitoes that we happened to catch outside the teaching lab here in Dar es Salaam where we are currently teaching a course. The scope mod kind of happened out of this following suggestions to simplify the FlyPi design for some applications. Notably, this is very much a work in progress...

Note also that some of the electronics on the back of the FlyPi are not used in this mod (this just happened to be the PCB we had around...)

description.text:
A case for the Adafruit Mini Thermal Printer that won't look out of place on any desk.

With mounting areas for 3 5mm LEDs, Adafruit Mini Thermal Printer (https://www.adafruit.com/product/597), button, Freetronics Buzzer module (http://www.freetronics.com.au/products/sound-and-buzzer-module) and a 10mm hole on the side for power, it comes together nicely for your next thermal printer project. Contains a spacious inside to mount an Arduino and other electronics and rests back to provide better viewing angle.

A full write up on the case and code examples coming soon to Prototyping Corner (https://prototypingcorner.me)

After printing, you may wish to glue/melt the main body and side piece together to provide better stability and overall stuctual strength. This can be done carfuly with a soldering iron and moving at a constant speed arount the perimeter (being careful not to burn the plastic).

You may also wish to add rubber feet to the bottom of the case so that it doesn't slide when the button is pressed or when removing the printout.

title: Monkeyz
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
'Monkeyz' is a fun moving one piece print that requires no support and at standard sacle uses less than 20gm filament including a raft. With a well set up slicing app and machine Monkeyz should be ready to swing through the trees (and from all sorts of other things) straight off the build plate....

This is a novelty print that can be placed in all sorts of locations at home, work, classroom, workshop and more... they provide a fun little decorative feature. Just place them anywhere they will hang... but they can also stand on their own two feet or sit. They look particularly good positioned swinging through house / pot plants.

The design has arms that rotate around the shoulder 360 degrees, legs that swing forwards and backwards approx. 180 degrees in total, and a tail that rotates up just over 90 degrees. However, it is a one-piece-print that requires no support. On a precise well sliced file and with an accurate machine Monkeyz should be ready to hang and swing straight of the build plate. The legs were designed to move together to make it easier for Monkeyz to stand.

Monkeyz look great printed in any colour. There is a lot of detail in the face and the arms, legs and tail have been designed to hang and swing as well as possible within the constraints of 3D printing. At standard scale Monkeyz stand 95mm tall (excluding the tail which swings up).

This is an easy print but please refer to the print settings (as this needs to be printed with extra shells to make the joints as strong as possible) and view the images provided for additional information... and please post images of your Monkeyz for others to see!

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs. .

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm / Standard in PLA

Infill:

3 shells / 25% or more infill recommended (to ensure joints are as strong as possible)

Notes:

Raft is recommended for easy and safe removal from the build plate. Do not use automated support as that could cause joints to fuse together.

3 shells and 25% or more infill is recommended to ensure the models joints are as strong as possible (but still take care as the joints are thin so can break if excessive force is applied).

Just remove the raft then find places to hang and swing your Monkeyz....

Take care with Raft removal to ensure the fine joints are not damaged / broken. The joints should be free straight off the build plate once the raft is removed.

comments.text: can these be printed smaller?
comments.author: arenton

comments.text: Potentially yes you can scale them down uniformly by 5 - 10% if you use a precise slicing app and have an accurate well set up machine.  The risks are that (1) reducing the size will make the internal clearances smaller so the parts are more likely to fuse and (2) it won't be as strong... so use extra high infill.

title: Cuisenare Set Generator with Inset - Math Manipulatives

description.text: Use this generator to create any configuration of blocks for your math manipulative needs in customizer. Use customizer to create the units you need!

For example, in the image we have created a single cube, a 2x1 unit, a 2x2 unit, a 2x2x2 unit and a 4x4x1 unit. These units can be used in conjunction with Chip Trading (https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/chiptrading/id521568609) in learning binary. In this configuration, these block are binary base blocks. We have all used base 10 blocks in our quest to teach place-value concepts. Not only do these blocks extend our base trading games and concepts of place value, they introduce the importance of the binary system in electronics and computer engineering. Children learn how the string of 0'Âs and 1'Âs are really a sort of on off system, which opens up a whole new understanding of how things work! This is just one example of what you can create in Customizer. Make your own cube configurations!

description.text: ribbon

This is the Soldering Iron Station using Chinese "Hakko T12" handles with quick changeable cartridges. The main T12 design advantages are the very short time-to-ready (~8 seconds to 260 Celsius) due to 70W power and integrated heater design, wide carttidge tips range available, very fast and easy cartridge replacement, sleep mode (that is really cool due to short heating time). All parts to build this station are available from common online markets. Designing the case I wanted to build it as small as possible keeping in mind some points like cooling, display location, top surface buttons location (to be able to press them by one hand with no need to hold the device by other hand), angles power cable plug (as the workbench usually is littered by some parts/tools and the straight protruding power cable is interfering with all that) etc. Rotary encoder is also used (not sure it is so necessary but I do really like them). The station dimensions are 113 x 64 x 51 mm and the weigth assembled 285 g (the station itself not including handle etc).

The HeaT12 BOM:

  • 24V PSU (the station itself consume upto 70W so that PSU have a little margin and that is fine) - http://www.banggood.com/4A-To-6A-24V-Switching-Power-Sup[email protected]Q

  • T12 Controller (small one) - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Digital-Soldering-Iron-Station-Temperature-Controller-LCD-for-T12-Heating-Core/32721267526.html

  • C8 Power Inlet (really that is C7 inlet while C8 is the plug) (bought 10 pcs trying to use that connectors in all my designs) - https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/IEC320-C8-Black-2-Terminal-Power-Plug-Inlet-Socket-AC-250V-2-5A-10-Pcs/2325001_32700599711.html

  • Rocker Power Switch - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/5pcs-x-AC-250V-3A-Right-Angle-3-Pin-SPDT-ON-ON-Snap-In-Mini-Boat/2034151348.html (they are not available now but you can search for the same 13x8 mm type)

  • M16 5-pin Plug+Socket - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/M16-16mm-5-Pin-Screw-Type-Electrical-Aviation-Plug-Socket-Connector/32650216149.html (not available but now you get what is needed)

  • Rotary Encoder with short Shaft - look for "Plum handle 15mm rotary encoder" at Aliexpress

  • 50x50x15 mm 12V Fan - used Sunon GM1205PHB3 from some disassmebled device

  • StepDown module to power up the Fan as it should be powered by 12V while PSU provide 24V (something simpler could be used like resistor but I do not like the idea of some additional heat source inside the case) - http://www.banggood.com/Small-Mini-360-Adjustable-DC-Power-Supply-[email protected]Q

  • T12 Handle & Cartridges you need. I have ordered that set https://www.aliexpress.com/item/2pcs-soldering-handle-4pcs-T12-soldering-iron-tips-T12-K-D52-JL02-IL-soldering-iron-tips/32656581005.html and replaced the wires with soft silicone: 2x AWG18 + 3x AWG24 (the handle can be connected by just 3 wires - Power, Ground, Vibration Switch, - but AWG24 are not so expensive) placed inside the silicone tube.

  • Vibration switch placed inside the handle (sleep mode) - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/SW-200D-Vibration-switch-Ball-switch-Tilt-switch-Double-bead-Angle-sensor-10pcs-lot-free-shipping/32372107733.html

  • Wires, M2 + M3 screws & nuts

Print the case and knob+buttons, assemble, use your old soldering iron and - voila, here is the new one, better, faster, wonderful! And cute! Due to pink fluorescent ABS bought at my daughter requests (but 1Kg is too much even for that requests).

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

25

Notes:

Printed using ABS: 0.3mm nozzle, 0.15mm layer, 110C heat bed @260C.
The slicer is calibrated to provide 1:1 dimensions and no excess thickness (that is 2mm wall width in design = 2mm wall width in printout)

author: michmelar

title: My FPV Ground Station
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Playing around with TinkerCad and setting up my FPV Ground Station. Includes a holder for the Dragon Rider Drak Diversity VRX with a Fatshark Goggles hanger. A Transmitter Hanger and a Battery holder. It also has Ball feet made specifically for my stand.
Pole hole sizes are dependant on my particular setup.
At this point these are work in process since I am tweaking as I go.
I originally wanted to use nuts and bolts to mount but in this case I am securing
with zip ties at the moment.
The Drak VRX holder is slip fit to the diameter on the top of the pole.
Again originally it was idealized having a 1/4-20 nut or sleeve encased
into the ABS. At the moment the slip fit works great and may stick to this.
I will likely use hot melt glue to further secure it to allow for a somewhat easy removal .

title: Random Probability & Percentages
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is an example of a random variable and is approximated by the probability distribution called normal or Gaussian distribution.
PLINCO!
The ball can land in randomly in any of 10 catches.
So all things being equal there is a 10% chance that the ball will land in any of the catches. BUT start closing off some of the catches and everything changes. 10 catches open out of 10 = each catch has 10% chance of winning
9 catches open out of 10 = each catch has 11.1% chance of winning
8 catches open out of 10 = each catch has 12.5% chance of winning
7 catches open out of 10 = each catch has 14.3% chance of winning
6 catches open out of 10 = each catch has 16.6% chance of winning
5 catches open out of 10 = each catch has 20% chance of winning
4 catches open out of 10 = each catch has 25% chance of winning
3 catches open out of 10 = each catch has 33.3% chance of winning
2 catches open out of 10 = each catch has 50% chance of winning
1 catch open out of 10 = catch has 100% chance of winning

Replicator2, Makerware Medium settings. PLA
These parts all print without rafts or supports.
The theory is the Makerbot "cool gray" play field is one solid piece. The white parts are (re)moveable.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l6KNXAu21XA

Love Hive?  Are you tired of your opponent accidentally brushing the tiles and knocking them all higgledy piggledy?  Print out some of these stackable game boards and you'll greatly improve your Hive experience.
Note, I'd love any ideas on a way to "hook" the boards together so they stay together better.  Thoughts?

• Print
  • Play
  • Try to surround your opponent's queen bee.

comments.text: Nice model! I've created a website to gather all board game improvements to inspire and showcase. Would you be interested in adding them to the Board Game Level Up site? I could help you with it, but still giving you the credit. www.boardgamelevelup.com
comments.author: RobhJ

comments.text: Yeah totally!  Let me know if you need anything from me.  :-)
comments.author: RobhJ

comments.text: Great, thank you. If you create a user or give me an email to use and I'll create a user for you. So I can connect the items to you so you'll have the control to edit or delete them in the future if you want and also gets the credit for making it.
comments.author: Gilgamesh82

comments.text: I PM'ed you my username.  Thanks!
comments.author: RobhJ

comments.text: Inset neodynium magnets for that satisfying "snikt".
comments.author: donstratton

comments.text: You could try to connect them with a wall having a Y-piece in both ends.
comments.author: garismaatti

comments.text: That's a good idea.  Unfortunately, not quite.  Expand that idea into the full size piece and you'll see what I mean.  The Y pieces will end up overlapping when you try to connect 3 segments together.  I've got a new design I think will work and am trying to print it now.  I keep jamming though.  :-(

Model expressions and equations on a number line with positive and negative jumps. Print out positive and negative jumps, and then place them standing up on the number line to build expressions. Create two expressions that both start at zero and end at the same place to form an equation. This is a powerful hands-on modeling tool to help students bridge the gap between modeling situations and symbolic representations. Teachers: I've included two worksheets (pdf files) that students can use use along with this manipulative. The worksheets include examples of how to use the tool. Here are the Common Core standards associated with this manipulative:
K.OA.2, 1.OA.1, K.OA.2
2.MD.6, 6.NS.5 and 6.NS.6, 6.EE.2 and 6.EE.6 I've include the SketchUp source files (in the zip archive).

If you want both positive and negative sides on your the number line, print out these parts and snap together:
NumberLine_Positive.stl
NumberLine_Negative.stl If you want only the positive side, then print out these parts:
NumberLine_Positive.stl
PositiveOnly_NumberLine_Cap.stl I don't have a dual extrusion printer, so I obtained the black numbers and ticks on the white background by starting out with white filament, and then pausing at 4.4mm and switching to black filament. Looking forward to learning how to make dual-extrusion capable files.

I printed positive jumps green and negative jumps red, but the color obviously doesn't matter. Here I got the black numbers on the colored background by switching filament at 3.8mm.   
I grouped the jumps into sets of small positive, large positive, small negative and large negative. There is also a "negative zero" jump as a separate file if you want to model subtracting a zero.   
I've included the source files (SketchUp), so one can easily break out individual jumps as needed. Let me know if it would be preferable to have these already broken out into separate files.
I've included a couple of worksheets as examples of math problems that one might use with this manipulative. The worksheets have examples at the top which might be helpful.

Earrings with a hint of glass.  Not too much

WARNING! (sand down sharp edges of the clasp and be careful when putting on and taking off!. if it feels too tight, re print to larger size to fit, which will increase the mouth opening of this ring. This is meant as a design in progress. Use your own common sense judgement about its use)

the ring wirs itself is 2mm. Diameter of the ring is 20mm.

I made the clasp part small to minimize its appearance and to look more like a real pierced ear ring on ear.and put the bumps in an attempt to give it ability to hold weight of ear ring charms. I test printed with ABS, and it seems to be fairly durable to spread a few millimeters for application, but found the edges are sharp and can draw blood. I filed down to round out the edges and had less trouble. I may make a few different sizes to accomodade more range of ear lobe thicknesses. I am also exploring rounding out the edges in the file itseld and incresing the size of clasp pads for more comfortable fit. I welcome your comments.

I designed this to use on piercing free ear for my jewelry. This is a ear nose ring clasp (20mm diameter) for ears/noses that do not have a piercing.. Be careful to file or sand down sharp edges before putting on ear or other body parts. I will be making other models of ear ring clasps. THis clasp can be used in conjunction with my ear ring charms. This clasp can also be used as a nose ring fo rthos without a piercing in nose. Please send me your comments and suggestions.

UPDATE: I have add accessory links to attach to the main ring and the the attached charms. It is 9mm diameter to outside edge, the wire is 1mm diameter and has an opening to allow for linking up lings together as well. Print as many links as you like. the file is a 1 link file

Safety issues: I am been researching what i Can find out about the use of PLA or ABS on the skin (as inthe form of slaps and nostril area.. I am could not find much and what little i did find suggests conflicting information about it.. It seems it leans more towards it being relatively safe under norbal conditions because the melting temperature is over 200 degrees.. and body tempartures usually average under 100 degrees max for for healthy people. I am not clear if there are any issues below melting point and at what temperature that would be.. So do your own research on what you think about it in terms of safety. And if you are in doubut, you might want to refrain from using as clasp on body parts. And if any of you have any more information please share. I suppose alternatives include having parts printed with known nontoxic materials for piercings?? If there are any??)

description.text: This is a clock that tells you if you guessed the right time! When someone moves the hands on the clock, two rotating discs attached to the hands will move under the clock face as well. When you guess what time the hands on the clock are pointing to, you can uncover the bottom panel and it will reveal the true answer! Demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FTeHo4a8FYM Optional dual extrusion method! - See "Instructions" tab for more details

The studs on each face are for guidance purposes only. I highly recommend using glue on the bottom of each face instead of just trying to press fit it. Parts List:
1 x Clock Face
1 x Base Housing
1 x Hour Hand
1 x Minute Hand
1 x Hours Disc
1 x Minutes Disc
1 x Cover Optional - DUAL EXTRUSION ONLY:
1 x Clock Face - DUAL EXTRUSION
1 x Cover - DUAL EXTRUSION
1 x Minutes Disc - DUAL EXTRUSION
1 x Hours Disc- DUAL EXTRUSION Start with the Base Housing. Set the Minutes Disc into the Base Housing, and then set the Hours Disc into the Minutes Disc. Next, put the Clock Face on top and fit the 3 grooves from the Base Housing into it. After that, put the Hour Hand into the hole in the Clock Face, and put the Minute Hand into the hole in the Hour Hand. When inserting the two hands, make sure the Hour Hand is pointed toward the 6 on the Hour Disc and the Minute Hand is pointed toward the 30 on the Minute Hand. Finally, slide the Cover into the slot on the bottom of the Clock Face. DUAL EXTRUDER USERS:
If your printer has a duel extruder, I have provided 4 extra, optional files you may use. These files will allow you to color the numbers and marks on the discs and the face a different color to see more clearly. Simply plate the - DUAL EXTRUSION files with their counterparts and set each file to use a different extruder. (Cover is plated with Cover - DUAL EXTRUSION, etc).

description.text:
One of the Pro Comp center caps on my alloy 3rd party wheels came off from my Toyotal FJ and was lost. I tried to order a replacement but no luck (all the wrong size). 3D printing to the rescue.

The outside dimension of the hole on my alloy wheels is 107.6 mm.

The originals had a wire spring that held those in place. My replacement uses friction so probably a good idea to use Shoe Goop to ensure that doesn't work its way off.

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

low res

15%

Notes:

Printed with 5 outer shells for strength. Because of the size, it will tend to warp without a heated bed.
Spray painted the print with mirror paint. I plan to print out a Logo and glue that on the outside of the cap to jazz it up.

remixed_from.title: Ginny Weasley Wand from Harry Potter

title: Ginny Weasley's Wand - with Core
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This all started when I wanted to print the fantastic wand that was designed by Superstar_beki but wanted to print it broken up vertically rather than horizontally, and rather than having to stick the pieces together, create some sort of screw fitting........but what is a wand without a core?!

In true Wizarding World fashion, I have created a wand where you can print whichever core has picked you! Why not try....

A cherry red dragon heart string
A pearly white unicorn hair
A golden phoenix tail feather

This wand is printed in 4 parts. A handle, a central section, a tip and a core. The core is used to hold all the other 3 sections together, and remains hidden inside the wand. The core can only be revealed by unscrewing the tip and removing the central section.

WARNING: Always ask permission of the wand owner before revealing the core - it is magical after all and can be temperamental. Unfortunately, we can not be held responsible for any spells back-firing.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The wand_core will need to be printed with a raft, the other files can be printed without.

All printed in Faberdashery's fantastic PLA:
Ginny Weasley Wand - Woodland Brown
Luna Lovegood Wand - Desert Tan
Elder Wand - Earl Grey
Dragon Heart String Core - Cherry Sour
Unicorn Hair Core - Pearly White
Phoenix Tail Feather Core - Bling Bling Gold
Elder Wand Core (created by death himself) - Smoky Black

Assembling Your Wand
  1. Screw the core into the handle
  2. Slide the central section over the core
  3. Screw the tip on to the end of the core

title: 1806 to 2204 Motor Mount Extension for a WingWing Z-84

description.text:
I needed an adapter to mount a Emax 1806 motor on the back of my WingWing Z-84, however the 1806 motor is too small to be a direct replacement as the prop would hit the back of the WingWing Z-84.

This adapter matches the standard hole mountings 16mm / 19mm of the WingWing Z-84 and extends the mount out ~29mm so that the smaller 1806 motor & 6" propeller can be used for a longer, more efficient flight.

You'll need to finger tighten the bolts in first, then use the allen key to tighten them. Thread lock is suggested!

Print with an infill of at least 30%, this is a motor mount after all!

You're very welcome to edit & improve upon this design! Matt

author: Moggiex

description.text:
This is a cryptex game designed to help students learning basic addition, subtraction, multiplication and division.  Once they find the solution to the equation the cryptex will open and reveal whatever prize is left inside!   
The equation tumblers on the body do not effect the locking mechanism.  They can be turned and snap into place to create numerous equations.  
The 2 tumblers on the cap are what lock and unlock the cryptex.  They are designed to be able to change the answer to unlock it to match the answer to the equation on the body.  
Check the instructions for more info on assembly and how to change the unlock code.  Enjoy!

Body x 1
Body Cap x 1
Top x 1
Equation Symbols x 1
Equation Numbers x 2
Solution Numbers Inside x 2
Solution Numbers Outside x 2 All pieces may have to be scaled to fit different size printers For Body you can print the body, body cap, equation symbols an 2 equation numbers and assemble them after they print. Once you have the number and equation rings on the body you simply screw the cap on the secure them. For the Top the top, 2 solution numbers inside, and 2 solution numbers outside need to be printed and assembled in a specific order. First print the 2 solution numbers outside rings. These will need to be fit on the 2 solution numbers inside rings while they are printing. Before the top of the solution numbers outside ring print make sure to pause the print (if you set it to change filament it will pause and lower build plate on some printers) which will let you place to solution numbers outside rings on and get sealed in. Once you have 2 sets of inside and outside solution numbers printed and assembled you need to do the same thing with the Top. Print the top pausing the print to place the rings on before they get sealed in. The tolerances should allow all peaces to fit snug which is important to being able to spin the answer side freely and still be able to change the answer for each equation. To change the answer you have to line up the solution to "open" and while holding the inside ring spin the outside numbers till they snap to the new solution.

description.text: Wanted to make an actual tension/stretched skin drum completely from 3D printing -- so I did. This drum uses 4 quarter inch bolts at least 2.5 inches long to draw tension on a head; similar to a standard drum you see on a drum set or marching band. Except -- this one is entirely made of PLA (or what ever you choose) and is 3D printed. I only played a little bit with my sticks at 3 inches (pp if you want a dynamic marking); I was too nervous to break it to really lay into it. It does however play well with fingers. Considering I thought it was going to break I'm quite happy with it.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Only the Rim needs a Raft and Support, everything else I was able to get to print without them; but know your printer, maybe you won't need it. Feel free to experiment with different infill levels; for my prototypes I use 30% consistently. This does have some long prints -- over 10 hours on my Robo 3D for the shell.

After everything is printed rafts and supports are cleaned off. From here you would assemble the drum exactly like you would any other. Before you put the head on line up the rim with the shell. I didn't quite get things centered perfectly; it does fit but only in one spot.

In case you don't know how or have never headed a drum here are the steps:
(After lining up the rim)
1) Place the drum head on top of the shell with the curve going down.
2) Place the rim on top of the shell and head.
3) Put the bolts through the holes of the rim and shell and put the wing nuts on VERY loose, just enough to keep them there. (With this drum I flip it upside down after I put in the bolts to make it easier to put on the wing nuts)
4) Tighten slowly -- it is a plastic head after all. Tighten exactly like a car tire just not as intense. Pick a spot to start then go straight across, then almost across then straight across all the way around the head. (this drum only has 4 lugs so all the way around the head is 2 times. In the video you can see me do a quick tighten to get the drum higher in pitch)

Also if anyone prints the head with a stretchy material I am interested to see if/how well that works out. Might need to tweak some things -- might be better -- might not make sound or perhaps better sound. Also, might hold up to sticks better.

Picture this: You're just getting ready to film your breakthrough documentary on Cholula Hot Sauce, but during your "research" you accidentally bathe your prized video camera in that very condiment. Your dreams, and your camera's electrical innards, seem short-circuited.
But wait! Your Galaxy Nexus has a fine camera on it. Why not use that? Alas, there's no easy way to mount it to your tripod! You might find a mount on here, but then you have to go find a nut to thread it into your tripod, and thats annoying.
Well, if you happen to have the same el-cheapo tripod that I got somewhere like 10 years ago, then you're in luck!
This Thing is a basic tripod mount for the Galaxy Nexus. Its tapered just like the nexus, so slap it in your tripod, place the thin end of the nexus in the slot, and then just slide the phone towards the fat end until you're happy with how snug it is. It can fit pretty tight if you want it to! It certainly won't fall out. Its made to fit the tripod quick release I have, but I think most cheapie tripods still use the same setup.
Don't have the same tripod? I Uploaded a special version just for you! Its got a hole for a hex nut in it so that you can put a 1/4-20 nut in it and it should work with any standard tripod! I haven't tested that yet, but will update when I can. (UPDATE: Works great!)
Notably, this was designed for the US Verizon LTE version, which is thicker than the International GSM version. If someone tells me how thick the thing is in the middle and 20mm each direction from there, I can easily whip up a version for the GSM variety.
Solidworks 2012 source files as well as IGES included, for maximum not having to edit STLs.

Print, and engage in tripod mount. Slide phone in thin end first. The slot is tapered, so make sure you have it facing the right way. You may need to flip the phone over or rotate the mount 180 degrees in your tripod. I prefer it in the power-button down configuration. The other way the volume button gets in the way. UPDATE:
I added a chamfer on the outside edge on one side, to indicate how the taper goes. The chamfer is like an arrow, pointing towards the fat end of the phone (the direction you should slide it). I also made the taper less, as there was a bit of error with my previous version. This one should fit really well! (UPDATE2: It doesn't fit better. I think my printer has some belt slack that is causing the very slight angle to get muted some. I will try printing at 45 degrees to force both motors to be moving more during the taper and see if that helps. Or perhaps I mucked up the angle. It still works pretty darn well though) I also added files that now will fit a 1/4-20 hex nut (7/16" wide) so this can be used with any standard tripod if you don't have the same one as me. I added a bit of extra slop for the nut so that if your printer makes holes too small, you won't have to chisel out a hex shaped hole. That does mean you may want to glue the nut in after, or adjust the file to your liking of course! The solidworks file has two configurations, one with the hex hole and one without.

description.text:
The Bit Buddy is a tool for teaching the binary (base-2) number system.  Understanding how computers encode data is an important first step towards understanding modern computing.  Students can physically manipulate the four bit values by flipping each of the four tabs to 1 or 0.  By flipping the tabs it is possible to display all 16 values in a "nibble" (4 bits) of information.   
If a tab is set to 0, no value is shown, but if a tab is set to 1 the value of the corresponding bit is shown.  The total number of dots that appear on the Bit Buddy corresponds to the value of the nibble.  
This tool associates a tactile and visual quality to bit values and gives a fun physical interface to an abstract concept.  Students can simply manipulate the values and observe the results.

This is a set of cards, sorting lid, and keys to teach binary numbers from 0 to 31 OR to use to teach the concept of sorting via dichotomous key with T/F, Y/N questions.  
The long square keys are for True or 1 bits, the long cylindrical keys are for False or 0 bits.  
Print 5 each of the T and F keys, one sorting lid, and 32 blank cards, then use diagonal cutters to cut either the square "True" or "1" or "Yes" notches, or the "False" or "0" or "No" notches, out of the upper edge of the cards. An example "10100" or "decimal 20" card is included as an example. (you could design and print 32 different kinds of cards, but really, it's easier to just print them all blank and cut them.)  
Obviously this is a very simple example of something with a very long history: Jacquard looms, Hollerith cards, the McBee keysort system, etc. This is a simple intro to the concept.  
With a change in scaling this could also accomodate standard index cards, punched with a one-hole punch.  
EDIT: finally got to print a trial of this, uploaded resized T and F keys that should fit better in the card slots to allow freer movement.  
OH NO- problem with the printer, interfering with optimizing this design and getting example prints made. This will be addressed as soon as I'm printing again.

Basic use: Stack the cards (aligned with their bevel on the right side) in the sorting lid, which is also beveled. Slide the proper keys into each of their holes. They are indexed so that they only go one way, and each has a flat end for writing 1 or 0 or T or F or other code on the end. When you pick up the lid, only the properly-coded card should fall out. For instance, if you have properly cut out your notches in the cards, inserting 1,1,0,0, and 0 keys in that order (left to right) should allow only the decimal #24 card to fall out. For teaching dichotomous or single-key sorting, assign each set of holes a Y/N or T/F or other question. By answering each question, only the cards satisfying all the conditions will fall out when the lid is picked up. Possible questions to ask: Why doesn't this work (i.e., multiple cards fall out) if you only put keys in the "1" positions? Isn't a 0 just like having "nothing" there? When making a dichotomous key, you are selecting only for the card(s) that satisfy "A" condition AND "B" condition AND "C" condition, etc.
This is the AND function. How would you make a system that uses the OR function? What would be the best questions to ask to sort out single students in our class, with the least number of Y/N questions? Demonstration: by using only one T key, you can do the classic "binary sorting" trick to sort shuffled number cards back into numerical order.

description.text: BIv25 3D printer's original extruders failed after 1-2years of use. So I've replaced them with this remake extruder and it working very well for the long PTFE tube. Clear PLA was used to print.

Doesn't Matter

Yes

25%

Notes:

Other parts required :

4x12mm M3 screw (or 3x16mm with 3 washers)
1x20mm M3 screw
5x M3 washers
1x M3 hex nut
1x 608zz ball bearing
1x bowden clip

I had only 4 M3x16mm, so I've used a saw to cut one to 12mm.

The little cap was printed at 99% scale, 195C extruder, 50C heatbed with decrease in temp.

Instead of spring to add pressure on filament, I've used 5 M3 washers to the 16mm screw, and adjusting pressure with the screw itself.

Cleaning

I used a drill to clean the holes to let the screw go freely (takes less time to screw them to the motor).

title: Reinforced Prusa X Carriage with Slim LM8UU Holder

description.text:
This is a reinforced Version of Simon's x carriage based on my slim LM8UU holders. I basically changed the following:
  • Beefed up the LM8UU clamps to 3mm wall thickness for better strength
  • Added extra support braces for stiffer frame, also between the belt clamps to allow more belt tightness without twisting the clamps or the whole carriage
  • Applied two fan mounts for multi-purpose fan or equipment installation (tiltable fan duct, LED ring light, etc.). Dimensions of mounting blocks are 10x10x15mm with hole for M3 screw right in the middle..

Slice, Print. 25% infill is just fine.
I'm using slic3r with 25% rectangular infill at 45 degrees, 3 perimeters, 3 solid layers, 0.25mm layer height and 0.35mm nozzle.

title: Unit Vec A Dot B = Cos Theta

description.text: So math was one of my favourite subjects at school thanks to some truly wonderful teachers. However I always found the way I was taught trigonometry was rather obtuse. This device can be used with students who are familiar with some basic concepts from geometry and algebra to visualise how the cosine values used in trigonometry can be computed using a unit vector dot product. The interesting thing is that when one of the vectors is [1,0] the cosine is simply the x value. Here is a quick youtube video that explains it... http://youtu.be/AQ0t7twdW-M In the example provided we have an angle of 60° which is π/3 radians, so the unit vectors are A[0.5, 0.866] and B[1,0]. The dot product formula is Ax∙Bx+Ay∙By=Cos ø, however because By is zero, the result is 0.5. Now if we compute the dot product of another two points that we know are 60° apart, namely A[-0.5, 0.866] and B[0.5, 0.866] we get -0.25 + 0.75 for the x and y values, arriving at the same answer, 0.5. If we turn the dial π/3 radians (or 60°) we see the same value in the cosine plot. See instructions for information on how to print and construct this device...

You need to print one of each stl object in order to recreate this device.  I used multiple layer colours for Object #1 pausing at 0.5 and 1.0mm and two layer colours for Object #4 pausing at 2.1mm.  
Best to sand the channel and sand and debar the rails that slide inside them. Clean thoroughly afterwards, and grease the channel with a bit of synthetic PTFE grease. The parts were glued together with super glue.
